Job Title: UKRI Senior International Policy Manager - Official Development Assistance
Job Description:
Interview Date: 9th December 2020

Background to the Role

What is Official Development Assistance (ODA)?

ODA-funded activity focuses on outcomes that promote the long-term sustainable growth of countries on the OECD Development Assistance Committee (DAC) list. The main ODA focus for UKRI, managed through the International Development Team, is the Global Challenges Research Fund (GCRF) and the Newton Fund.

The Global Challenges Research Fund (GCRF) is a £1.5 billion fund announced by the UK Government to support cutting-edge research that addresses the challenges faced by developing countries through:

Challenge-led disciplinary and interdisciplinary research
Strengthening capacity for research and innovation within both the UK and developing countries
Providing an agile response to emergencies where there is an urgent research need.

The Newton Fund is a £735 million UK investment Fund, with partner countries providing matched resources within the Fund. The Fund was launched in 2014 and extended and expanded in 2016.

The Newton Fund aims to promote the economic development and social welfare of either the partner countries or, through working with the partner country, to address the wellbeing of communities. It will do so through strengthening partner country science and innovation capacity and unlocking further funding to support this work.

UKRI is the largest GCRF and Newton Fund Delivery Partner, but significant activity is also delivered through the Learned Societies, UK Space Agency, the British Council and the Met Office.

The International Development Team works closely with other UKRI areas such as UKRI International. The team reports to the UKRI International Senior Responsible Officer, Professor Andrew Thompson.

Detailed Role Description

Three roles are available within the UKRI International Development (ID) Team; two are open-ended positions and one is for a fixed term of 12 months. All roles require a similar skill set and support related activities, successful candidate’s preferences, experience and expertise will be used to determine the exact distribution of work.

The main purpose of the roles is to help shape and deliver the Funds by supporting the operation of the GCRF and the Newton Fund. The GCRF and Newton Funds have some very novel characteristics; you will support the design, implementation and management of activities, making an important contribution to the development of the strategy, policies, operations and organisation of GCRF and the Newton Fund.

The roles require a pro-active and imaginative approach as well as excellent planning, engagement and communication skills. You will need to have or be able to quickly gain an understanding of the breadth and complexity of UKRI operations and work effectively with colleagues across the UKRI Councils. You will need to build positive relationships across Councils and with external stakeholders, including internationally.

Posts may include line management responsibilities.

The posts are wide ranging and varied.

Key responsibilities

All roles:

Co-ordinating internal UKRI networks, and working closely with other teams in UKRI
Prepare briefings and provide information and advice on UKRI ODA activities to the UKRI Councils, other delivery partners, the research community (both UK and international), and UK Government departments
Working with, and representing UKRI to, key stakeholders and external networks
Contribute more broadly to the development, management and delivery of the international development team.

International Development Partnerships (Fixed Term, 12-month role):

Contribute to the development of GCRF and/or Newton Fund Strategies, including support for cross delivery partner groups and senior cross-UKRI policy groups
Strategy formulation, stakeholder engagement, facilitation and coordination associated with working on a variety of ODA strategy areas including bi- and multi-lateral partnerships
Developing interdisciplinary research and capacity building calls and running these calls including managing the peer review process
Portfolio analysis, including integration of internal and external information to develop and support the GCRF and/or Newton Fund strategies
Leading and contributing to GCRF, Newton Fund and ODA projects
Developing partnerships with external organisations, including joint programmes and developing relationships within a regional focus.

ODA Policy and Compliance (Open-Ended role):

Lead on the process of continuous improvement to ensure the development and implementation of ODA best practice, policy and compliance, including leading the cross-UKRI approach
Review guidance and best practice for ODA peer review purposes to ensure that councils continue to have the best practice guidance they require to successfully set up, run, peer review, monitor and report on ODA activities and funding
Work with colleagues to ensure that our ODA processes and reporting are fit for purpose for funding assurance requirements
Work with colleagues in the UKRI Funding Policy Team to ensure that new and/or revised funding policies reflect the unique characteristics of ODA funding requirements
Lead on engaging with the Reforming Our Business process to ensure that ODA policy requirements are embedded in new business processes and functions
Work with colleagues in the UKRI Funding Policy and Funding Assurance teams to establish and implement procedures for ensuring organisation eligibility to receive ODA funding from the Councils, particularly for overseas organisations
Provide a focal point for advice within UKRI, other delivery partners and with BEIS on best practice for ODA
Lead projects to develop, implement and promote UKRI ODA policy, responding to external and internal requirements e.g. equitable partnerships, equality and diversity etc
Work with appropriate university groupings and research offices to ensure they are developing and following best practice for ODA activities – particularly through whole life cycle
Ensure the UKRI colleagues have the necessary skills, knowledge, systems and capacity to enable them to fully meet ODA requirements under Newton Fund and GCRF activities.

Preventing Harm (Safeguarding) Policy and Compliance (Open-Ended role):

Lead on the development and implementation of UKRI Preventing Harm policy and compliance, including leading the cross-UKRI approach
Lead on ensuring the policy is responsive to changes in best practice guidance or evolving expectations/requirements from BEIS
Lead on reviewing, evaluating and reporting on the policy’s impact and effectiveness
Actively engage with UKRI research and innovation external community and other external stakeholders – provide guidance and best practice information as required
With UKRI Funding Assurance and UKRI Research Culture Directorate, monitor the implementation of Preventing Harm policy by UKRI funded organisations, including by funded overseas organisations
Contribute to cross-Government safeguarding initiatives, including the UKCDR Safeguarding Project and FCDO-led activities
Work with other funders to ensure, where appropriate, coherence and alignment of approach and expectation
Advise on the cross-UKRI organisational arrangements needed to implement and report on UKRI Preventing Harm policy, including arrangements for incident and casework management
Provide a focal point for advice within UKRI, other delivery partners and with BEIS on Preventing Harm and other safeguarding issues
Work closely with UKRI Research Culture Directorate to ensure alignment with other related policy areas, including bullying and harassment, research ethics and research integrity.

Organization Description

What is UK Research and Innovation?

Operating across the whole of the UK with a combined budget of more than £7 billion, UK Research and Innovation is a new entity that brings together nine partners to create an independent organisation with a strong voice for research and innovation, and a vision to ensure the UK maintains its world-leading position in research and innovation. UKRI will build on the successful elements from the current funding system and maximise the contribution of each of the component parts to create the best environment for research and innovation to flourish.

Building on success

The UK has a world class research and innovation system. Our expertise spans all fields of knowledge, from the discovery of penicillin and monoclonal antibodies, to the jet engine and the world-wide web. Our inspirational creative industries are strong in art, design and the innovative use of new materials and technologies. Our universities and laboratories produce a disproportionate percentage of the world’s top research, and their academics are highly-sought as international colleagues and co-authors and are among the world’s best at attracting overseas students Nor is this excellence confined to university campuses and research centres. Our engineering, automotive and pharmaceutical industries are successful in part because of the superb graduates they can hire and the top rate researchers that support them.

Our partners

The nine UK Research and Innovation partners each bring unique assets to this cooperation. Innovate UK helps businesses to identify the commercial potential in new technologies and turn them into the new products and services that will drive economic growth and increase productivity; Strong discipline-facing Research Councils encourage breadth and diversity, curiosity-driven research, and priority-driven initiatives; Research England’s work on knowledge exchange will focus on capacity and culture in universities and provide balance to the funding system. It will drive quality and impact through the REF and work closely with its counterparts in the devolved administrations.

Shortlisting and Interview Criteria

Essential:

Research policy: A comprehensive understanding of the work and role of UKRI, and the broader UK and international landscape for research and innovation
Interpersonal skills and relationship management: experience of working with senior leadership, able to develop relationships with senior leaders and a wide range of senior stakeholders
Strategic insight: demonstrate an understanding of the wider political and strategic context, together with experience of strategy development.
Communication: demonstrate strong oral and written communication including experience in provision of high quality written and verbal advice suitable for executive and senior level decision makers
Team working: Ability to influence and persuade others, and to work with people of all levels and to build good relations with them
Leadership: experience of leading activities and teams
Ability to work under pressure: experience of working in a fast-paced environment, dealing with competing priorities and tight deadlines.

Desirable:

Experience of developing and/or delivery of research and innovation calls for proposals, including peer review support and call guidance
Experience of working in an international development/ODA context and an understanding of UK Aid strategy, the contribution of research to overseas development and Official Development Assistance (ODA)
Experience in undertaking desk-based research
Degree or equivalent experience
Foreign language skills
Experience in international/cross-cultural working.

As the posts may involve some overnight UK and international travel the successful candidate will be expected to, and must be able to, undertake such travel as necessary.

UKRI supports research in areas that include animal health, agriculture and food security, and bioscience for health which includes research on animals, genetic modification and stem cell research. Whilst you may not have direct involvement in this type of research, you should consider whether this conflicts with your personal values or beliefs.

Job Title: Software Engineer (Generalist C++ for Engine, Platform & Framework)
Job Description:
Software Engineer (Generalist C++ for Engine, Platform & Framework)

Position Overview

Our shared technology team are looking for people with a passion for core engine systems in a cross-platform environment.

As a generalist, you have a love for programming and software engineering across multiple platforms to make code easy to understand and maintain, well documented and portable. Through excellent software engineering principles, you can make your code work across multiple platforms and devices as well as projects and products that use our engine and frameworks.

You have a great eye for clean and well-designed code, and you can architect systems from ground up to meet all requirements.

You will be joining our dynamic shared technology team, reporting into the Technical Director, where you will be improving and maintaining existing core systems as well as adding new functionality across our engine and frameworks. You will also be ensuring optimal performance.

You have worked with multiple programming languages, but your main language is C++. You are up to date on the latest developments in the language and have experience with modern C++.

The work we do is fundamental for all our games as well as internal and external tools.

Key Responsibilities

Identify and fix issues in our engine code across several platforms on a variety of devices and operating systems.
Improve and replace existing functionality across our code base.
Re-engineer existing code to meet new and changing requirements.
Implement new technologies.
Own areas of engine code and maintain and support them across all supported platforms.
Improve our tools, workflows and working practices.

Knowledge, Skills and Experience

Excellent C++ knowledge, including modern C++.
Minimum three years of professional experience using C++ as the main language.
Experience with cross-platform development, working on code that is used across multiple platforms.
Experience of writing core engine systems, frameworks and other shared code that is used by other teams, projects, and products.
Experience of developing for iOS or Android is beneficial.
Ability to write clean, maintainable, portable and well documented code.
Excellent understanding of performance and optimisation.
Excellent analytical and problem-solving skills.
Excellent communication skills and ability to work in a team as well as independently
Experience with other programming and scripting languages.

Studio Overview

Sports Interactive (SI) is a multi-award-winning game development studio and the world’s leading developer of sports management simulations. Founded in 1994, SI became a wholly owned subsidiary of SEGA in 2006. Based at the Here East technology hub in Stratford, East London, the SI team continues to expand as it brings its titles to an ever-growing audience via an increasing variety of delivery platforms.

SI has enjoyed sustained commercial and critical success for its extremely detailed and immersive simulation experiences. Its games are amongst the highest-rated PC titles (according to Metacritic) and frequently occupy both the ‘top selling’ and ‘most played’ charts on Steam.

The Sports Interactive team is diverse and international, bringing together world class and high potential talent with a combined passion and drive for creating genre-defining games. Team members enjoy a flexible working schedule and a relaxed studio environment that encourages a close-knit, collaborative approach to game development.

SI is an equal opportunities employer and encourages applications from suitably qualified and eligible candidates regardless of sex, race, disability, age, sexual orientation, gender reassignment, marriage or civil partnership, pregnancy or maternity, religion or belief. Our studio has disabled access and facilities.

SI offers a generous benefits package to all full-time team members including gym membership, in-house massage therapy and private healthcare (including dental). The studio is also a London Living Wage employer and proudly boasts one of the lowest staff turnover rates in the industry with just over 30% of the current full-time team members having been at the studio for 10 years or longer. SI also has many longstanding partnerships with leading charities, local schools and major sporting organisations.

Further information on Sports Interactive, its games and life at the studio can be found at www.sigames.com.

What you'll do

Please note this role is for the Infrastructure and Projects Authority, Government Digital Service supports departments across government with DDaT (Digital, Data and Technology) recruitment.

Location: London or Birmingham

The Infrastructure and Projects Authority (IPA) is the government’s centre of expertise for infrastructure and major projects. We sit at the heart of government, reporting to the Cabinet Office and HM Treasury. We have a unique view from the centre of the whole portfolio and our purpose is to continuously improve the way infrastructure and major projects are delivered. We aspire to create the best performing project system of any country in the world.

Projects in government cover a very wide spectrum, from massive infrastructure projects such as HS2, through to military equipment, information technology and transformation projects. Additionally, the Government has embarked on a Transition Period after our exit from the EU that has a large portfolio of enabling programmes. The breadth and diversity of our portfolio is greater than any in the private sector.

Job Overview

You will hold a critical role within the Project Delivery Team of the Infrastructure and Projects Authority, leading challenge and support activity across a number of Departments.

You will also have accountability for improving project performance through strategic and tactical support, advice and appropriate assurance of Departmental portfolios. This includes projects and programmes that form part of, or are candidates for, the Government’s Major Project Portfolio (GMPP).

The Role & Responsibilities

As the Lead Project Delivery Adviser your key responsibilities will include:

Leading the IPA’s delivery challenge and support across a significant part of the Government’s portfolio working across multiple Departments and project types with an emphasis on technology enabled programmes in Home Office, HMRC, and MoJ;

With and through your team, building and maintaining the assurance and approvals framework for your Departments. Engage Cabinet Office and HM Treasury partners to align perspectives, as well as controls, in the interests of successful delivery; representing IPA on HM Treasury approval panels;

Taking shared leadership accountability for meeting key performance indicators and assisting Departments to deliver their Comprehensive Spending Review commitments while taking a balanced view on wider transformation.

Build and cultivate strong, trusted relationships with senior stakeholders (e.g. Senior Responsible Owners and Programme Directors) to enable collaborative working relationships. Creating strong professional networks at the heart of government, particularly within the Home office, National Crime Agency, Ministry of Justice, HM Revenue & Customs, and with HM Treasury.

Where needed, Support the activity and actions of Senior Civil Servants in the IPA on senior/ complex projects.

Deputising for the Deputy Director and represent the IPA with Home Office, MoJ and HMRC portfolios as well as lead on the major HMRC programmes.

Who you are

It is important for the IPA to ensure our staff have the right expertise to advise on an ever increasing number of digital transformation programmes in order to deliver the Government's priorities.

As a Project Delivery Adviser you should have:

Robust leadership maturity and excellent management skills. Must be capable of promoting and delivering continuous individual and team development to enhance people capability

Major project delivery experience, particularly gained in DDaT projects, including a robust understanding of the end-to-end project life cycle and the risks that need to be managed in major projects particularly in Home, Tax, & Legal

Ability to think strategically in, working with senior leaders to maintain oversight and provide challenge and support to project delivery

Very acute stakeholder engagement skills; confident in influencing and negotiating with both peers and very senior leaders

A well founded track record in building good working relationships across diverse business areas and functions

Effective critical thinking and analysis skills for problem-solving;

Confident and effective personal communication; highly developed drafting skills

In addition to the person criteria above, we’re also looking for staff who are confident active learners and self-managers able to make the best use of our current situation in 2020/ 2021.

Experience of working to a Project Methodology.

About the job
Summary
The Business Strategy Directorate is at the forefront of the Department’s agenda to join up and reform our services and ways of working by developing innovative approaches to solutions, adopting a strategic approach, actively building relationships, influencing and driving activity to effectively deliver DWP ambitions and objectives.

This is an extremely high profile and exciting area of work that, whilst challenging, is pivotal to setting, embedding and proactively accelerating forward the future vision for DWP.

The successful applicant will have an opportunity to design, shape and landscape the programme of work with colleagues across the Department. Stakeholders include senior leaders (e.g. Executive Team and their representatives), major change programmes, digital, people and capabilities, analysts and business architects.

By collaborating with colleagues both within Business Strategy Directorate and across the wider Department, you will support the Director and Deputy Directors and other senior leaders to understand the key strategic choices that we need to make in order to achieve DWP’s future business strategy.

This role will give you the opportunity to demonstrate new ways of working and influencing with a wide range of stakeholders, embedding and leading multi-disciplinary activity to actively drive the business strategy, ensure that barriers to delivery are understood, choices are grounded in evidence and ministerial priorities are reflected.
Job description
You will lead a small flexible team within the business strategy division, progressing work in two main areas, the roles will require the post holders to:

· Set the direction for DWP through the Target Operating Model (TOM), interim operating models (IOMs) and supporting products, collaborating across the organisation to communicate a coherent vision for service delivery in the future, the sort of organisation we want to be, the capabilities we will need and how we will meet the changing needs of customers who interact with us.

· Lead DWP’s input to wider Civil Service Reform, utilising the champions network in DWP and across Government to influence plans for reform and to ensure DWP views are represented.

· Understand and use the TOM and IOMs to influence and actively progress design decisions, strategic reviews, evidence gaps and alignment with other operating models, through strategic stakeholder engagement to create deep understanding and adherence throughout the business and its functions.

· Help re- set the organisation following the coronavirus epidemic and ensuring the DWP strategy is at the heart of many difficult choices the department needs to make.

· Work closely with colleagues across the department engaged in strategic and transformation activity to develop a coherent plan of long term activity which gets us to our long term vision for the business strategy, ensuring this fits with financial planning (including the Spending Review) and developing tools to measure progress and track performance along the way.

· Build strong positive relationships across and beyond the Department, with external stakeholders and with the Executive Team and their representatives to promote the value of the business strategy, the TOM and supporting products, gaining buy-in and collaboration.

· Identifying the business needs and priorities and developing the right skill sets to achieve the division’s objectives.

Responsibilities
Essential criteria:

You have a track record of strong leadership – with the ability to build high performing teams, understand business needs and respond by identifying the capabilities required to deliver these. You will be comfortable working with ambiguity, working proactively and independently and thrive in a fast-moving, changing environment. Delivering complex work at pace; be flexible in approach and thinking, to learn quickly in a high profile environment.

You are a highly articulate communicator and are able to engage and influence stakeholders internally and externally. Comfortable at communicating effectively at all levels with the ability to adapt your style to ensure maximum impact. You demonstrate the ability to be an excellent storyteller, able to communicate our vision and ambition to a range of audiences and to persuade and inspire colleagues and stakeholders.

You will have experience of engaging and influencing stakeholders internally and externally. Very strong relationship management skills are required – building credibility and a powerful network of partnerships and engendering trust and consensus to enable collaboration at all levels.

You have experience of working strategically. You have strong strategic thinking skills and the ability to focus on the long term whilst understanding and articulating complex issues and collaborating on the development of cross-cutting policy or delivery solutions. You are able to generate new ideas and opportunities; thinking laterally and have the ability to give life to those ideas, negotiating across boundaries to achieve the right outcome. You are able to produce high quality work at pace.

You have a broad understanding of DWP business – you are comfortable with DWP's governance and decision making models at both a process and cultural level.

You have a good understanding of programme disciplines and agile ways of working, ensuring that work is effectively planned, managed and risks mitigated, and that we take a test and learn approach.

You have well developed analytical skills – experience of analysing various complex sources of information and intelligence coherently and succinctly, bringing together a variety of perspectives and sources to identify key trends and emerging issues, as well as the ability to weigh up data from various sources, recognising when to bring in experts/researchers to add to available information.

Desirable skills:
Knowledge of Systems Thinking and how to apply this and other business design methodologies (e.g. soft systems methodology/organisational change approaches). including knowledge and curiosity about how other organisations, both in the public sector and beyond, are leveraging technology to transform the way they deliver value to their customers.
Understanding of the wider business environment into which solutions will land and ensuring alignment to the Departmental Business Architecture and its Capability Models.
The ability to blend a creative and innovative outlook with deliverability, translating and understanding how concepts and ideas are brought to life in a practical setting.
Strong workshop design and facilitation skills and translating outcomes quickly to keep momentum.

Our team looks beyond the headline questions to understand the real issues behind them, drawing on multiple sources of information on the provider sector and our knowledge of the policy and regulatory landscape. Business unit information

The award winning Commercial Capability Team was formed in 2014/15 to bolster departments in improving their commercial capability. A new concept for government, we have developed a suite of capability services that central government departments and wider government bodies can access. A Commercial Recruitment Hub has been created, offering a centralised recruitment service for departments to fill commercial vacancies starting from Commercial Managers progressing up to Senior Commercial Specialists. Within this hub there is a pool of centrally-employed and accredited commercial professionals that can be assigned to departments to work on commercial assignments. Once in the role, these individuals have access to training and accreditation programmes, they are assigned their own commercial career coach and benefit from a tailored talent management service. We want to be the best commercial function in the United Kingdom. Thus the Commercial Capability Program has been created to attract, retain, develop and reward these specialists, to ensure we appeal to the best in the commercial sector to come and join us. Along with providing departments with this talent pool, as a Commercial Capability Program, we also support central and wider government in commercial capability training, advice and guidance.

This role will sit within the Commercial Blueprints Team, a team critical to the success of the overall Government Commercial Function (which the Commercial Capability team sits within). It supports Commercial Directors across Whitehall to explore, test, strengthen and articulate their functional strategy and delivery plans in areas such as operational models, organisational models, functional governance and influence, stakeholder relations, systems and technology usage and so on.

The scale and complexity of this function means that we must have data at the heart our work; using insights to underpin commercial strategies, enable effective decision-making and improve the overall understanding of the function.

Working in the centre of government you will influence how the GCF uses data to create insight that improve our strategy, policy and delivery.

Current working from home arrangement apply. Post Covid-19, the role will be based in London (10 South Colonnade, Canary Wharf) or Manchester (Trinity Bridge House, 2 Dearmans Pl, Salford, M3 5BN). If based in Manchester, travel to London may be required on occasion to attend team meetings etc.

Job Description

ROLE OVERVIEW

This is an exciting opportunity to work in a unique organisation at the heart of Government and to create a lasting impact on how we make decisions about business strategy.
Reporting to the Head of Blueprints, you will be a crucial member of the Blueprints team, responsible for delivering functional, operational and commercial insight to internal stakeholders and other Government Departments in order to improve central policy, departmental strategic planning and operational delivery capability.
Working across all Government Departments (and increasingly the Wider Public Sector), you will develop effective data collation, analysis and communication methods. This will involve improving and defining the processes and tools used by the Blueprints Team to analyse departmental data and feed into the wider Blueprint process.

The role offers the opportunity to undertake a varied set of tasks, these include developing departmental specific dashboards, conducting analysis across large datasets to establish benchmarks, identifying trends and generating important insights to develop recommendations that will lead to improvements in the overall commercial functional strategy and operations.

Although there are core deliverables, we would like you to shape the future of the way we conduct, promote and make use of data and insight in our work.

The outputs will benefit the departments who will use these cross-departmental benchmarks and department-specific insights to strengthen their operating model and identify areas of transformation focus. It will also benefit the Function who will assimilate a macro picture of the function, thus informing central functional strategy and priorities.

We are looking for someone eager to learn, motivated and inquisitive about trends, who will inspire others to look to data for the answers. A passion for research, for accuracy, for seeking the story within data and communicating it effectively is key for this role, as is the ability to engage effectively with the senior stakeholders across Whitehall, the wider analytics practice and other colleagues within GCF.

KEY RESPONSIBILITIES

• Study data from a range of sources and systems from across Government, providing insightful and actionable reports back to the team and wider colleagues across Cabinet Office.
• Coordinate data collection and data cleansing; ensure data requests from central teams are produced in a way that is aligned to data standards and a common data model. Identify and develop opportunities to improve data completeness, timeliness and quality.
• Conducting deep-dive research to explore and explain emerging trends, providing concise summaries and recommendations based on the insights found.
• Building and managing a network of technical, commercial, legal and policy colleagues across core Government Departments to improve common understanding of data and help create a ‘Community of Practice’.
• Identifying innovative ways of communicating insights to a variety of stakeholders, reflecting the diverse nature of the Blueprint’s customers (from Permanent Secretaries through to less technical stakeholders).
• Suggesting and implementing improvements in the way Government uses data to inform commercial decisions.
• Bolster the team in monitoring departmental spend, benefits/impact analysis and providing internal reports for management.
• Opportunity to help shape internal systems design for cross-Government data visualisation.
• Work with stakeholders from each department to identify, develop and refine management information.
• Issue data requests to departments, keeping track of progress, actions and next steps.
• Provide support and guidance to departments in making effective decisions based on data available.
• Be a good team player who is proactive and able to work effectively with little direction.
• Work with other parts of GCF to improve service and data automation, including working with GCF Data and Insights team to build a sustainable plan for Blueprint’s data over the coming years.
• Maintain and update dashboards for departments and the GCF.

EXPERIENCE / SKILLS / CAPABILITIES

Essential:

• Highly numerate and technically skilled
• A good communicator - ability to engage with colleagues, host workshop/working sessions and the ability to address issues from departments when necessary
• Excellent analytical skills – ability to draw insight from data (with high proficiency in tools such as MS Excel and Power BI to support this).
• Understanding of advanced analytics solutions (NLP, Machine Learning, statistical analysis) including Python or R.

• A passion for data manipulation and finding trends in data

About the job
Summary
Do you want to help the UK reach its climate change goals? Do you have a passion for using evidence to underpin policy making? We want enthusiastic professional analysts to join our Energy and Security Analysis team, working on issues that have a real impact on everyone’s everyday lives.

In 2019, the Government set an ambitious target for the UK to reach net zero carbon emissions by 2050. To help us reach that target we need to make decisions now about the way we generate and use energy in the future, as well as ensuring that our energy system is both affordable and secure. Those decisions need to be underpinned and informed by high quality analysis. In the Energy Security and Analysis team, we play a fundamental role throughout the policy cycle, from development through to implementation and evaluation. The team of around 50 multidisciplinary analysts work together using a range of techniques including modelling, appraisal, evaluation and data management, to help set the direction of policy. We are a friendly and encouraging team dedicated to professional development, equality and diversity, and offering an accommodating working environment. Many people in the team have flexible working arrangements, including part time and compressed hours

We will ensure that individuals with disabilities are provided reasonable accommodation to participate in the job application or interview process, to perform crucial job functions, and to receive other benefits and privileges of employment. Please contact us to request accommodation.
Job description
We are looking for a number of professional analysts to join the team. The roles are open to badged Government Operational Researchers, Statisticians, Economists or Social Researchers, OR those who can demonstrate the relevant knowledge and experience to meet the professional membership requirements at Grade 7 level (more details provided under “Person Specification”).

International energy trading and offshore networks

In this role, you will be responsible for building the evidence base to support policy decisions about how we trade electricity and gas with Europe. Your modelling of the energy system and appraisal of the different options for future trade will inform both our negotiations with the EU as well any legislative changes which follow. As we establish a new energy trading relationship with the EU and form new trade agreements with non-EU countries, you will lead our analysis on the role that interconnectors – the undersea cables through which we trade electricity with other countries – will play as we move towards a decarbonised and flexible power system.
Alongside this, you will be responsible for building the evidence base to inform policy decisions about the way that our offshore electricity networks are developed. This is an increasingly important area of focus as the UK aims to quadruple its offshore wind capacity over the next 10 years.

Gas decarbonisation

The way we use gas at the moment – for heating, industry and power generation – will need to change as part of meeting our decarbonisation goals. We are expecting the use of natural gas to decline as electricity takes over in some areas, whilst hydrogen and green gas will play a growing role alongside.
In this role, you will be responsible for building the evidence base to inform how we decarbonise the gas system, with a particular focus on understanding the impacts on gas networks, security of supply and market structures.
Additionally, Net Zero will require the UK’s oil and gas industry to change. An additional part of this role is to support the industry’s transition, considering the impacts on jobs, infrastructure and the changing supply and demand of fossil fuels out to 2050.
This is an emerging work area in BEIS which will add to a growing programme of work on our Net Zero gas strategy.

CfDs

Contracts for Difference (CfDs) are the Government’s flagship policy and delivery mechanism to meet our renewables ambitions and ultimately contribute to our net zero target. The contracts are determined by a series of auctions that have a number of design parameters that need to be developed through robust analysis to meet policy objectives and provide value for money.
This post is critical to successful delivery of those auctions to make sure that we get the renewable electricity generation that we need. In this role you will be responsible for leading a policy facing analyst team to develop the evidence base, input into the auction design and articulate the trade-offs of different choices.
This is a challenging role that will contribute to a high profile policy area with critical delivery milestones in the next 12 months.

Electricity systems modelling

This is a key post for BEIS, working on the department’s model of the GB power market, to ensure the delivery of robust and influential analysis. Achieving net zero by 2050 is likely to rely on electrification of a range of sectors, making analysis of the electricity market key to understanding the overall trajectory of decarbonisation.
Our main modelling tool, the Dynamic Dispatch Model, is used to project generation and investment decisions. The timescale of analysis ranges from the next few years (to inform decisions over e.g. carbon pricing or security of supply) out to strategic analysis of 2050 and beyond. The model underpins all major electricity policy decisions, and its importance is recognised by senior colleagues, ministers, other government departments and industry.
You will be working as part of a multi-disciplinary team, taking responsibility for updating and developing parts of the model, and delivering analysis on a range of different policy areas.

Nuclear policy analyst

The UK’s current nuclear fleet forms an essential part of a diverse energy mix, providing reliable and carbon-free electricity generation. Nuclear policy areas range from new nuclear builds, disposal of nuclear waste, decommissioning of plants at the end of their life, protecting the UK’s civil nuclear infrastructure, exploring the potential of new nuclear technologies and more!
This role sits within the analytical team supporting the two nuclear directorates within BEIS and provides an excellent opportunity to be involved in the delivery of legislation over a range of areas.
You will work as part of a multi-disciplinary team and be involved with longer-term projects, as well as quick turnaround ad hoc requests for data and analysis, in a role that will involve working with senior policy officials and analysts within BEIS as well as other public bodies and Government Departments.

Responsibilities
In all cases, the roles will provide opportunities to:
• use existing models and analytical tools to build the evidence base and inform thinking in relation to the UK energy system;
• lead analytical work programmes, including developing new analysis and tools – e.g. through developing novel methods or procuring external research and consultancy;
• work with a range of partners, such as legal, commercial and technical specialists from within the Department, across other Government departments as well as external organisations such as Ofgem and National Grid; and
• oversee and develop junior analysts.

Person specification:

We are seeking someone with an enthusiasm for developing and using analysis to help influence policy decisions.

Essential criteria:

• A proven track-record of developing and overseeing high-quality and influential analysis, such as data analysis, modelling, cost-benefit analysis, option appraisals, quantitative research or evaluation.
• Strong communication skills, in particular, around ensuring analysis is accessible to decision-makers and the public.
• Proven leadership and organisational skills to manage analytical workstreams and ensure delivery of both fast-paced work and longer-term projects.
• Strong collaborations skills to work with policy teams and external partners.

Technical requirements:

You must be a full member of one of the analytical professions Government Social Research Service (GSR), Government Statistical Service (GSS), Government Economic Service (GES) and Government Operational Research Service (GORS).
Or
You must be able to demonstrate that you satisfy the eligibility criteria and have the competence at the required grade (Grade 7) for one of the professional bodies. Links are provided to the relevant professions below:

Government Economics Service -
https://civilservicelearning.civilservice.gov.uk/sites/default/files/ges_cpd_-_grade_7_and_6.pdf

Government Operational Research Service - http://www.operational-research.gov.uk/recruitment/competencies/
Government Statistical Service - https://gss.civilservice.gov.uk/policy-store/competency-framework-for-the-government-statistician-group-gsg/
Government Social Research Service -
https://www.gov.uk/guidance/the-government-social-research-competency-framework

To join one of these professions, you’ll need as a minimum to meet one of the following qualification standards:

Statistician: A degree at 2.1 (or above) or an MSc in a subject with substantial statistical content e.g. Statistics, Mathematics, Economics, Sciences, Business Studies, Psychology, Geography or similar)

Find out more at https://gss.civilservice.gov.uk/careers/joining-us/

Social Researcher: For qualification route, must hold an undergraduate degree at a minimum of 2:1, or 2:2 with a postgraduate degree, in a social science subject. Qualifying social science subjects are those that contain substantial social research methods training (comprising around one-third of modules taken in the course).

For professional experience route, must hold an undergraduate degree at a minimum of 2:1, or 2:2 with a postgraduate degree, in any subject, or hold a degree equivalent, and have at least 4 years’ social research practice experience. Social research practice experience consists of experience working in a research agency, market research agency or specialist research team.

Economist: A degree at 2.1 (or above) in an undergraduate degree with at least 50% economics content, or an MSc in Economics and be able to demonstrate substantial current experience in your career as a professional economist.

Operational Researcher: A degree at 2.1 (or equivalent) or an MSc in a highly numerate subject, or equivalent experience, and be able to demonstrate relevant experience in your career in a relevant profession.

Job Description

Director, Sales - Legal & Compliance

The Director, Sales for the Legal and Compliance product lines is responsible for growing the Corporates Europe Legal and Compliance product lines by identify new revenue opportunities through new and existing customer channels. This role is accountable for delivering sales across their region of Thomson Reuters’ full line of Legal and Compliance products for our Corporates clients. The Director, Sales must foster collaboration across the various Thomson Reuters and Corporates Segment functional lines of business to develop sales strategies and enable the methodology required to maximize sales across a broad customer base. We are looking for a candidate with an entrepreneurial spirit who is comfortable with risk, highly customer-driven, ability to define a strategy and drive focused execution.

Our technology drives global markets and helps professionals around the world make decisions that matter. Our customers rely on us to deliver the intelligence, technology and human expertise they need to find trusted answers. The business has operated in more than 100 countries for more than 100 years. Whether solving for today’s challenges or tomorrow’s aspirations, you will work with the industry’s brightest thinkers on diverse projects, creating next-generation solutions that deliver powerful results. As the world’s leading provider of intelligent information, we want your unique perspective to create the solutions that advance our business—and your career.

Bring your passion for innovation and together we’ll make a difference.

Think Big, Make it Simple, Move Fast!

About the Role

As a Director, Sales at Thomson Reuters, you will:

Owning top-line sales metrics across Corporates Europe for all Legal and Compliance propositions sold to our Corporates Europe clients

Driving high-level prioritization and program/resource management through management of sales force and delivery of sales operations.

Coordinating with Marketing and Proposition teams to develop value proposition across the Legal and Compliance portfolio.

Developing the sales strategies for the organization and create a high-performing culture within the team

Creates a sales strategy that elevates and expand the relationships with Corporate offices across the customer base

Facilitates coaching of Sales Managers to lead their Sales Representatives and drive a high performance culture

Maintain active knowledge of competition and market.

Key Deliverables:

Delivery of target financial and strategy objectives for the Corporates Europe Legal and Compliance sales organization (e.g. gross sales [PY growth]); growth through cross-sell/up-sell, net new customer acquisitions, and product innovation (e.g. E/R ratio, client acquisition)

Refresh strategic workforce supported by active talent and succession pipeline (e.g. employee satisfaction); annual improvements in organizational effectiveness (client-centricity, customer approach, rapid decision making)

Accurate forecasting, customer evaluation and procurement reports; consistent achievement of sales quota, forecasted revenue, and unit targets; consistent update of all CRM systems / reporting on market and competitor activities

Client engagement with key clients to help drive the closure of complex deals

Presentations across internal meetings with other company functions necessary to perform duties and aid business development

About You:

To be our Director, Sales you will likely have/be:

Extensive global sales management experience, with specific experience within the B2B complex software solution sales environment and direct sales leadership

Strong operational and analytical skills with the ability to assess results and communicate trends and issues

Excellent client relationship management skills including influencing and building relationships with a wide range of stakeholders including senior management. Ability to communicate complex concepts to a broad audience.

Entrepreneurial approach, innovative, passionate, self-starter. Persistence despite obstacles or setbacks, comfort with ambiguity.

Flexibility in adjusting to new, different and changing business requirements and decisions. Ability to successfully lead in an agile environment

Demonstrable track record of recruiting, developing and retaining a high performing sales organization

An outside-in focus: outstanding end-customer relationship skills

Ability to understand and interpret fundamental workings and trends within target industry

Experience selling Legal and/or Compliance software and content solutions to corporations preferred

What’s in it For You

At Thomson Reuters, our people are our greatest assets. Here are some of the benefits we offer for your personal and professional growth:

You will have the opportunity to work for a company that has a market dominant position for both content and technology and is passionate about giving back to the community

You will be joining a growing sales team that has the commitment of the company to prioritize organic growth and has made investments to expand the sales team capability

You will be part of one of the key strategic objectives of the organisation

Base salary and a variable compensation that is directly related to your success

Extraordinary benefits package

Business Unit: Corporates Europe

Corporates Europe serves legal, tax, accounting, risk and compliance professionals in corporations across the UK, Ireland and Continental Europe. Our industry-leading products and services include highly specialized information-enabled software and tools – combined with the world’s most global news service – that help these professionals navigate the ever-changing regulatory and business environment.

Do you want to be part of a team helping re-invent the way knowledge professionals work? How about a team that works every day to create a more transparent, just and inclusive future? At Thomson Reuters, we’ve been doing just that for almost 160 years. Our industry-leading products and services include highly specialized information-enabled software and tools for legal, tax, accounting and compliance professionals combined with the world’s most global news services – Reuters. We help these professionals do their jobs better, creating more time for them to focus on the things that matter most: advising, advocating, negotiating, governing and informing.

We are powered by the talents of 25,000 employees across more than 75 countries, where everyone has a chance to contribute and grow professionally in flexible work environments that celebrate diversity and inclusion. At a time when objectivity, accuracy, fairness and transparency are under attack, we consider it our duty to pursue them. Sound exciting? Join us and help shape the industries that move society forward.

Accessibility

As a global business, we rely on diversity of culture and thought to deliver on our goals. To ensure we can do that, we seek talented, qualified employees in all our operations around the world regardless of race, color, sex/gender, including pregnancy, gender identity and expression, national origin, religion, sexual orientation, disability, age, marital status, citizen status, veteran status, or any other protected classification under applicable law. Thomson Reuters is proud to be an Equal Employment Opportunity/Affirmative Action Employer providing a drug-free workplace.

We also make reasonable accommodations for qualified individuals with disabilities and for sincerely held religious beliefs in accordance with applicable law.

More information about Thomson Reuters can be found on thomsonreuters.com.

At CLIC Sargent we are One Team with One Target. It is our mission to ensure that everyone under 25 with cancer, and their families, get the support they need to thrive, not just survive. As a member of the Income and Engagement team, you have a fundamental role in helping us to deliver on our promise to support young people and their families to deal with the effects of cancer, both during and beyond treatment.

We will do this by working with our supporters and donors in ways that most help them maximise the contribution they can meet to achieving this objective. This role, working together with others in the directorate and the wider Charity, will help us achieve this through professional support, engagement and stewardship.

MAIN PURPOSE

Sole responsibility for the administration of legacies to maximise the charity’s legacy income. As part of the Supporter Engagement team the role requires specialist knowledge.

To protect the charity and trustees from liability in relation to current probate, tax and Charity Commission law.

To use insight, case studies and trend analysis to provide forecasts, support others to build their understanding of legacies and inform and support legacy marketing decisions.

To provide a positive stewardship experience to those involved in the execution of a legacy bequest.

DIMENSIONS

To be responsible for legacy administration costs and the administration of legacy income of approximately £3m.

To be part of the team that supports and influences the understanding and approach to legacies across CLIC Sargent to ensure long term growth.

To provide information and insight to strengthen CLIC Sargent’s approach to legacy marketing.

PRINCIPAL RESPONSIBILITIES

Legacy Administration

To represent and protect CLIC Sargent’s interests in the administration of legacies, using detailed knowledge and understanding of current probate law, estate administration law, Institute of Legacy Management best practice and Charity Commission guidelines.
To make decisions on the valuation of chattels, the sale of property and land and on instructing solicitors to act on our behalf in contentious probate cases or defending claims against the estate.
To act with sensitivity, patience and empathy in relating to people who have recently been bereaved.
To regularly review all case files and ensure due payments are received in a timely manner and pursue any unanswered queries relating to estates.
To maintain detailed files of all cases, both current and archive, for the annual audit and HMRC investigation, providing supplementary information as required.
To scrutinise estate accounts and check Inheritance Tax calculations. Advising on the legitimate avoidance of Capital Gains Tax during the administration of an estate and on taxation matters in an estate generally.
To use legacy forecasting techniques to set realistic legacy income budgets and to provide accurate monthly reports on income, values in probate and new notifications.
To maintain the highest standards of legal knowledge and best practice and research the charity legacy market to identify trends and threats within the sector and how they could impact CLIC Sargent.
To actively participate in regular department and team meetings, contributing to strategy, discussions and decisions which will be beneficial to the Income and Engagement directorate’s activities.
Represent CLIC Sargent at internal and external events
Ensure effective management of agency and supplier relationships to deliver agreed services.
To develop and share insight and information that will support the development of future marketing and stewardship plans.

Compliance and Risk Management

Ensure all activities comply with appropriate legal, regulatory and fundraising good practice requirements and with CLIC Sargent policies and standards.
To offer support to CLIC Sargent volunteers in ensuring their activity is compliant.

Gift Aid

To maximise Gift Aid income and ensure full regulation compliance for designated area of work by identifying opportunity, responding to regulation changes or recommendations, implementing quality control and supporting and developing colleagues.

Specific expectations in key policy areas;

Everyone working in the Income and Engagement Directorate at every level, must:

Make safeguarding children, young people and vulnerable young adults a priority
Take care of your own health and safety and that of others
Ensure that you treat information and data professionally, using it only for the purposes that CLIC Sargent has said we would; respecting the confidentiality and privacy of our supporters, clients and staff and taking active steps to dispose of information and data when it is legally required
Treat your colleagues with respect and ensure that you are sensitive to and adjust any behaviours that they have reasonably indicated they find unacceptable

This means that in your role you must;

accept that you are personally responsible and accountable for ensuring you understand these policies and procedures regulation and CLIC Sargent best practice.
take active steps to do so and make sure that this is a priority in your daily work
make sure you attend any briefings and training to help you do so and co-operate with your manager
ask and request advice if you are not sure of your responsibilities

WORKING RELATIONSHIPS AND CONTACTS

To correspond and build positive relationships with solicitors, banks, relatives, other charity legacy officers and lay executors on all matters relating to estate administration. Specific areas include the requesting of Wills, Schedule of Assets & Liabilities, Estate Accounts and Tax Deduction Certificates.
To work with the Data Team to update and analyse the legacy information on the database assisting in the profiling of legacy prospects.
To work with the Management Accountant in the preparation of monthly legacy management accounts ensuring that this income is accounted for accurately, and to provide appropriate commentary and impact assessment for reporting to the Executive Team.
To work with senior management to provide accurate information and assessment on complex matters where the decision of the Trustees is required.
To work with relevant teams across the charity to ensure effective stewardship of supporters and an integrated collaborative approach

GENERAL RESPONSIBILITIES

Our values are a key part of who we are and what we do, it’s important that you have integrity, you are brave, you are confident and you work with others as One Team.
Responsible for leading cross team multifunctional projects as required
Adhere to the CLIC Sargent Equal Opportunities policy in all activities and to actively promote equality of opportunity wherever possible.
Any other reasonable duties as directed by or agreed with line manager.
To be a CARE and IT super user, and train and support other members of your team to be able to use our IT and CARE systems.

The responsibilities of this post and reporting structure will be periodically reviewed.

Job Description:
Assistant Director of Programmes

Role Context Background

Responsible for patient facing digital transformation programmes. Led by the Director of Digital Experience, the team drive policies and initiatives necessary to define and commission these transformational patient-facing digital services.

The aims of the team are to improve health outcomes, increase efficiency and importantly, improve patient experience. Our strategic goals are to empower people to navigate and manage their health and care using technology to learn and take more control, whilst creating a universally personal digital healthcare experience for citizens. We work across multidisciplinary programmes, government and in partnership with clinicians to deliver health outcomes enabled by relevant, connected and trusted digital services.

As a senior member of the Empower the Person team you will be expected to provide programme delivery expertise and leadership to enable the development, planning and implementation of key products in support of the wider Empower the Person agenda.

Where necessary, the team commissions delivery of tools and services, digital demonstrators to help shape strategic plans and defines engagement requirements, ensuring data / metrics are collected. Empower the Person works to support local and regional commissioning of digital services to drive uptake of national patient facing digital services by local health organisations, clinicians and the public.

Additional Role Specific Duties

The post holder will:
Assume the Assistant Director of Programme role for the programme
Support the SRO, in assessing the strategic alignment of the programme
Provide practical support to enable the clear, universal understanding of the status of the programme including scope, outcomes and deliverables, finances, delivery and implementation plans, milestones and dependencies
Contribute to developing a strategy to deliver:
nationwide access to digital records
Identifying and mapping stakeholders and working with the SRO to ensure:
Work closely with the Empower the Person PMO team and the Delivery Hub to ensure that governance and process is clearly understood and followed
Work closely with the CTO team to ensure that all proposed solutions are fit for purpose, strategically aligned and approved
Collaborate with programmes and teams across to ensure effective alignment and develop a sustainable and deliverable programme plan
Ensure that the programme has a clearly defined strategy, a defined roadmap and a clear delivery plan delivery that has appropriate Business Case cover
Ensure that information required about the programme is available for reporting as required in a timely fashion
ongoing roadmap to 23/24

communication of the strategy and vision, appropriate engagement and alignment with the needs of key customers

Knowledge and Experience
Experience of leading a programme through rescoping and redefinition
In depth additional expert knowledge acquired over a significant period of time in the following areas Transformation Change, Subject matter expertise across a number of key areas relating and Digital strategy
Proven and significant leadership experience and/or formal management qualification
Experience of working in a strategic national role as part of a senior team with appropriate levels of responsibility and accountability
Proven stakeholder engagement and management experience with experience of leading national strategy/policy development
Ability to successfully lead operations within a partnership environment
An understanding of the background to and aims of current healthcare policy and
appreciate the implications of this on engagement
Should have an appreciation of the relationship between the Department of Health, the NHS England and individual provider and commissioning organisations
Highly developed communication skills with the ability to communicate on highly complex matters and difficult situations
Ability to provide and receive, convey and present highly complex, sensitive and/or contentious information to large groups, responding openly to questions to ensure full understanding and engagement
Ability to communicate effectively with clinical, academic and all levels of staff High level analytical skills and the ability to draw qualitative and quantitative data from a wide range of sources and present in a clear concise manner
Ability to analyse numerical and written data, assess verbal, written, numerical and draw appropriate conclusions
Demonstrates sound judgement in the absence of clear guidelines or precedent, seeking advice as necessary from more senior management when appropriate
Demonstrable leadership, vision, strategic thinking and planning
Demonstrable Political acumen
Member of relevant professional body

Skills
Ability to develop, maintain and monitor information systems to support innovation initiatives
